You are going to read an article from a travel magazine. For questions 1-10, choose from the sections (A-D). The sections may be chosen more than once.

1 recommends paying the entrance fee? (1)……………
2 states that the beach has featured in advertisements? (2)……………
3 says visitors may be surprised by the water temperature? (3)……………
4 points out that the water is quite shallow? (4)……………
5 suggests visitors should take photos of the beach? (5)……………
6 says visitors can walk on the beach in their bare feet? (6)……………
7 mentions a pleasant smell from the trees? (7)……………
8 advises visitors to get to the beach early in the day? (8)……………
9 states that it is not always possible to visit the beach? (9)……………
10 warns visitors to the beach to protect their skin? (10)……………

***

**A   Rodas Beach, the Cies Islands, Spain**
Some of Spain’s most spectacular beaches lie in Galicia on the Atlantic coast, and perhaps the most stunning of these are on the Cies Islands. These unspoilt and uninhabited islands are a national park, with public access limited to the summer months, and contain the perfectly-shaped Rodas Beach with its pure white sand and clear blue sea. At first sight it almost seems tropical, until dipping your toe in the water encourages you to spend a lazy day on the beach rather than dive in for a swim. There you can enjoy the quiet, the warmth of the sun and the scent of pine from the nearby woods, and later on have an excellent meal in the reasonably-priced fish restaurant close to the beach.

**B   Whitehaven Beach, Whitsunday Islands, Australia**
Australia is famous for wonderful beaches, and Whitehaven must surely be one of its very best. Set against a background of amazingly-green tropical forest, and with views across the clear blue ocean to distant small islands, the sandy white beach is like something from a picture postcard or a TV commercial. As you would expect in such a sunny climate, the water is pleasantly warm, ideal for swimming on or below the surface. The sand, in contrast, always remains cool as it is of a type that reflects the sunlight, so you won’t need sandals. As the island has no permanent inhabitants, and most day trippers leave by boat quite early, in the late afternoon and evening you can have the place almost to yourself.

**C   Matira Beach, Bora Bora, Tahiti**
Matira Beach on the Pacific island of Bora Bora has incredibly white sand, beautiful fish swimming in clear blue-green water, and stunning sunsets. The air temperature hardly varies around the year, and neither does that of the ocean – which is only waist high even hundreds of metres from the shore. And unlike windier beaches nearby, Matira is quite well sheltered. There isn’t, however, much shade, so it is advisable to use plenty of sun cream, and the sand can feel uncomfortably hot unless you wear beach shoes or something similar. There is no charge to visit the beach, yet it rarely becomes crowded at any time of day. Everyone should go there at least once in life, and when you do, make sure you have your photo taken as the sun goes down.

**D   Anse Source d’Argent Beach, Seychelles**
This must be one of the most photographed beaches in the world, so don’t forget to get some shots of your own, especially of the sea and the sand framed by the background of enormous pink rocks, with tall palm trees right behind them. It’s easy to see why commercials have been made there. The patches of brilliantly white sand between those beautiful rocks make it the perfect place to spend a relaxing day, and it is well worth the small amount it costs for access. The best spots – those with both sunshine and shade – quickly get taken, so make sure you arrive well before the sun starts to beat down and the sand heats up.

You are going to read a newspaper article about an Olympic athlete. For questions 1-10, choose from the paragraphs (A-D). The paragraphs may be chosen more than once.

1 gives an example of Jessica having good luck? (1)……………
2 refers to the role of Jessica’s family in helping her achieve success? (2)……………
3 suggests it is surprising that Jessica does not understand herself better? (3)……………
4 mentions a previous sporting disappointment that Jessica had? (4)……………
5 explains why Jessica is so popular with the local public? (5)……………
6 explains why another athlete was surprised at Jessica’s performance? (6)……………
7 mentions a painful childhood memory? (7)……………
8 suggests that Jessica’s appearance can give a misleading impression? (8)……………
9 says that Jessica’s relationship with someone can sometimes be difficult? (9)……………
10 contrasts Jessica’s personality on and off the track? (10)……………

***

**A**
There have been many great Olympic athletes in recent years, but few have been taken to their country’s heart quite as warmly as gold medal winner Jessica Ennis. Her quiet determination to succeed, her good humour when faced by setbacks and the absolute joy she showed when finally becoming Olympic champion have all contributed to this, as has the difficulty of the sport she has chosen to compete in: the heptathlon. This involves turning in world-class performances in seven track and field events over two days. At first sight, Jessica – at just 1.65 metres and 57 kilos – may seem an unlikely winner of such a physically demanding sport, but once the action begins it soon becomes clear she has the speed, strength and endurance to beat anyone.

**B**
Jessica recognises that her normally easygoing nature is transformed into something much fiercer when she has to compete. She knows that success only comes from being highly motivated and totally focused on each event. In her autobiography Unbelievable, she talks of the way she was picked on at school by bigger girls because of her background and lack of size, and how that has made her determined to succeed, particularly against taller and stronger athletes. She also points out that she is not from a particularly sporting family and that her sister ‘absolutely hates sport’, but says she was introduced to athletics by her parents, who have continued to give her encouragement and support throughout her career as an athlete. Her mother was born in the UK and her father in Jamaica.

**C**
She gets on well with her family, as she does with her husband Andy, saying she dislikes conﬂict and wherever possible avoids arguments with people. The only exception is her trainer Chell, with whom she has a row ‘every day’. And although Jessica is a psychology graduate, she is unable to explain how she acquired the tremendous self-discipline that has enabled her to keep training to Olympic gold medal standard while so many others have given up along the way. Of course, at that level nothing can be taken for granted, as she discovered when a sudden injury put her out of the Beijing Games. She describes that as the lowest point in her career. Typically, though, Jessica bounced back, and once ft again began training just as hard as ever.

**D**
By the time of the London Games in 2012 she was in the best shape of her life, and on this occasion she was fortunate enough to remain free of injury. Some of the times she recorded in the heptathlon were so fast that she would have achieved good positions in the finals of track events such as the 200 metres. That brought to mind a race won two years earlier against the world champion, who couldn’t believe she had lost to someone who trained for seven different events. Since the London Olympics, Jessica has continued to take part in competitions, receiving numerous awards including World Sportswoman of the Year. She has also featured on a special postage stamp and has had a post box in her home city of Sheffield painted gold in her honour.

You are going to read an article about four young inventors who have created innovative solutions to problems. For questions 1-10, choose from the inventors (A-D). The inventors may be chosen more than once.

1 Which inventor was motivated by a family member's health issue? (1)……………
2 Which inventor faced initial skepticism from experts in the field? (2)……………
3 Which inventor had to learn a completely new technical skill for their project? (3)……………
4 Which inventor intends for their invention to be used in developing countries? (4)……………
5 Which inventor was inspired by observing a problem while on holiday? (5)……………
6 Which inventor combined a personal hobby with their invention? (6)……………
7 Which inventor emphasizes that their solution is cheap to produce? (7)……………
8 Which inventor believes their youth allowed them to think differently? (8)……………
9 Which inventor was surprised by how quickly their idea became popular? (9)……………
10 Which inventor hopes to reduce a specific type of environmental waste? (10)……………

***

**A   Boyan Slat – Ocean Cleanup**
While diving in Greece at the age of 16, Boyan Slat was shocked to see more plastic bags than fish. This depressing sight sparked an idea for a passive ocean cleanup system, using ocean currents to concentrate plastic, which could then be easily collected. When he presented his idea for a school science project, and later at a conference, many marine experts declared it impossible, arguing that a static system would never withstand the ocean's power. Undeterred, Boyan founded The Ocean Cleanup. He believes that being young and inexperienced was actually an asset, as he didn't know enough to say 'this can't be done', allowing him to approach the problem from a fresh angle that seasoned engineers had dismissed.

**B   Suman Mulumudi – Steth IO**
Suman Mulumudi was just a high school student when he invented Steth IO, a smartphone attachment that turns the device into a sophisticated stethoscope. The inspiration came from watching his father, a cardiologist, constantly juggling his stethoscope and his smartphone to record patient data. Suman realized he could combine the two. He spent weeks studying 3D printing and audio engineering to build a prototype. The resulting device not only listens to heartbeats but creates a visual graph of the sound waves, aiding in more accurate diagnoses. He aims to distribute the device to rural clinics in developing nations where expensive medical equipment is scarce, providing a low-cost, high-tech solution.

**C   Ann Makosinski – Hollow Flashlight**
Ann was 15 when she learned that a friend in the Philippines was failing school because she had no electricity to study at night. Ann wanted to help. She knew that the human body radiates heat, and she wondered if she could harvest that energy. The result was the 'Hollow Flashlight', a torch powered solely by the heat of the user's hand. It requires no batteries and no moving parts. Creating it wasn't easy; she had to teach herself about Peltier tiles and energy conversion from physics textbooks and online forums. She admits she didn't expect much attention, but after winning the Google Science Fair, she was inundated with media requests and offers to manufacture the product.

**D   Laurence Rook – Smart Doorbell**
Laurence, aged 13, was frustrated by missing deliveries of packages because he was out playing or at school. He figured there had to be a way to answer the door remotely. He combined his interest in electronics with basic coding to create a doorbell that connects to a mobile phone. When a visitor presses the button, it calls the owner's phone, allowing them to speak to the visitor. It acts as a security device and a convenience tool. Laurence managed to secure a deal with a major telecoms company almost immediately. He says the hardest part was balancing the business negotiations with his homework, but he is thrilled that his simple idea has turned into a commercial success.

You are going to read an article about four people who changed their careers drastically. For questions 1-10, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

1 Which person accepts that they earn less money than in their previous career? (1)……………
2 Which person realized they needed to change jobs after a specific moment of clarity? (2)……………
3 Which person feels physically healthier as a result of the change? (3)……………
4 Which person uses organizational skills from their old job in their new one? (4)……………
5 Which person faced concern from their relatives about their decision? (5)……………
6 Which person enjoys seeing the tangible results of their work? (6)……………
7 Which person found the retraining period particularly challenging? (7)……………
8 Which person works longer hours now but feels more satisfied? (8)……………
9 Which person turned a long-term pastime into a profession? (9)……………
10 Which person wanted a job that involved more social interaction? (10)……………

***

**A   Elena – From Lawyer to Baker**
For ten years, Elena worked in corporate law. The salary was fantastic, but the stress was unbearable. She spent her weekends baking bread and cakes for friends as a way to unwind. "One Monday morning, staring at a contract, I just hit a wall," she says. "I realized I couldn't do it for one more day." She quit and used her savings to open a small bakery. The early mornings – rising at 3 am – were a shock to the system, and her income has dropped significantly. However, she says the satisfaction of handing a warm loaf of bread to a customer is worth far more than her old paycheck. "It’s hard physical work, but I’ve never been happier," she admits.

**B   Mark – From IT Consultant to Landscape Gardener**
Mark spent fifteen years sitting in front of a screen. He suffered from back pain and felt constantly lethargic. He had always loved the outdoors, so when he was made redundant, he saw it as a sign. He retrained as a landscape gardener. "My family thought I was mad," he recalls. "They worried about the financial instability and the physical toll." The first year was exhausting, and his body ached every day, but soon he felt fitter than he had in his twenties. He loves the creativity of designing gardens and the feeling of the sun on his back. He says he sleeps better now than he ever did when he was in IT.

**C   Sarah – From Accountant to Primary Teacher**
Sarah was a successful accountant, but she felt her work lacked meaning. She wanted to do something that contributed to society. Switching to teaching was harder than she expected. "The training year was incredibly demanding," she says. "I was used to quiet offices, not a classroom of thirty energetic six-year-olds." However, she found that her background in planning and organization was a huge asset in managing lessons and paperwork. She misses the quiet coffees of her old life, and the workload is heavy, often spilling into evenings, but when a child finally understands a concept they were struggling with, she knows she made the right choice.

**D   David – From Marketing Executive to Furniture Maker**
David worked in a high-pressure marketing agency, creating campaigns for products he didn't care about. He felt a disconnect between his effort and the end result. He wanted to make something real. He had done some woodworking with his grandfather as a child and decided to take a course in furniture making. Now he runs his own workshop. "In marketing, success is abstract numbers on a spreadsheet. Here, at the end of the day, I can point to a table and say, 'I made that'." He admits that finding clients is stressful and requires him to use his old marketing skills, but the peace he finds in the workshop is irreplaceable.
